comment_data.body:
This one-liner effectively does the same thing without having to keep "global" state:

```suggestion
      new_config.cmd = { unpack(new_config.cmd or {}) }
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -42,37 +43,44 @@ return {
       return util.root_pattern '*.sln'(fname) or util.root_pattern '*.csproj'(fname)
     end,
     on_new_config = function(new_config, new_root_dir)
+      -- store the initial value of `cmd` for later use
+      if not cmd_init then
+        cmd_init = {}
+        for _, v in pairs(new_config.cmd) do
+          table.insert(cmd_init, v)
+        end
+      end
+      -- copy the fields of `cmd_init` into `new_config.cmd`
+      new_config.cmd = {}
+      for _, v in pairs(cmd_init) do
+        table.insert(new_config.cmd, v)
+      end
+      -- add hard-coded command arguments

comment_data.body:
Might as well also add this (see 2nd point [here](https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/issues/2392#issuecomment-1610129809))?

```suggestion

      new_config.capabilities = vim.deepcopy(new_config.capabilities)
      new_config.capabilities.workspace.workspaceFolders = false -- https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-roslyn/issues/909
      end
```

comment_data.body:
@williamboman It looks like I may have been bit hasty in my testing. While your suggestion to use `unpack` works when `cmd` is configured as a table with only one item (e.g., `cmd = { "omnisharp" }`), it fails if `cmd` needs to be instantiated in any other way.

For example, I've seen the following code suggestion in numerous places on GitHub, and it's actually included in the `docs` section of the same `omnisharp.lua` file:

``` lua
cmd = { "dotnet", "/path/to/omnisharp/OmniSharp.dll" }
```

In this instance, the line performing the `unpack` will simply assign `{ "dotnet" }` to `new_config.cmd`. Additionally, any other arguments that the end user manually passes into the program will also get dropped.

I don't see how we can accomplish what we're trying to without keeping "global" state as I had done previously, though I'm certainly no Lua expert. I'm definitely up for suggestions! And if I need to double back and stick with my original approach, I'd love to know if there's a more idiomatic way to accomplish what I was originally trying to do.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

     end,

+      -- store the initial value of `cmd` for later use
+      if not cmd_init then
+        cmd_init = {}
+        for _, v in pairs(new_config.cmd) do
+          table.insert(cmd_init, v)
+        end
+      end
+      -- copy the fields of `cmd_init` into `new_config.cmd`
+      new_config.cmd = {}
+      for _, v in pairs(cmd_init) do
+        table.insert(new_config.cmd, v)
+      end
+      -- add hard-coded command arguments

comment_data.body:
Huh, that sounds odd. So the only thing we're trying to do here is copy a list, so no need to change approach entirely.

`new_config.cmd = vim.list_extend({}, new_config.cmd)` is an alternative, and might even be more idiomatic.

comment_data.body:
Oh, very nice! And it seems that this change also renders the following line—and function parameter `new_root_dir`—unnecessary. Would you agree?

``` lua
vim.list_extend(new_config.cmd, { '-s', new_root_dir })
```

I've tested the code with the above line commented out, and it appears to work correctly by starting up a second OmniSharp instance when needed. And it consistently ties new buffers to the appropriate OmniSharp instances.

comment_regular_data.body: @williamboman My apologies, I should have marked the PR as a draft following your initial feedback. Anyway, I think my changes are ready to be reviewed.

Also, regarding the comment about using a "rebase workflow" in `CONTRIBUTING.md`... is there a practical way for me to consolidate my commits into one before merging, or is that something that can be done in the merge itself? Again, I'm sorry for all the questions: this is the first PR I've ever submitted in which I actually changed code.
